articles.headline: Wells Fargo Faces Scrutiny for Black Marks on Ex-Employee Files
articles.snippet: Three senators asked for data on forms filed by the bank, which former employees say contained negative comments as retaliation against whistle-blowers.
articles.abstract: Three senators asked for data on forms filed by the bank, which former employees say contained negative comments as retaliation against whistle-blowers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three senators fired at Wells Fargo’s new chief executive with fresh ammunition on Thursday: the hundreds of termination notices the bank filed with an industry overseer over the last five years as employees left the company in connection with its sales scandal.

articles.headline: At Trader Joe’s, Good Cheer May Hide Complaints
articles.snippet: Some workers at Trader Joe’s stores, including one who says he was fired for lacking a “genuine” smile, have complained about their treatment and of safety lapses.
articles.abstract: Some workers at Trader Joe’s stores, including one who says he was fired for lacking a “genuine” smile, have complained about their treatment and of safety lapses.
articles.lead_paragraph: To explain their infatuation with Trader Joe’s, fans of the offbeat grocery chain typically cite three factors: low prices, an appealing selection of high-end products and, perhaps above all, irrepressibly friendly employees.

articles.headline: You Might Be Paying Too Much for Your Chicken
articles.snippet: Investors contend that the way a chicken pricing index used by grocery stores is compiled has kept the retail price of chicken artificially high.
articles.abstract: Investors contend that the way a chicken pricing index used by grocery stores is compiled has kept the retail price of chicken artificially high.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beef prices at grocery stores are lower. So, too, are pork prices. But chicken? Steady as she goes.

articles.headline: Clinton Pushes Minority Turnout as Trump Tries to Rally His Base
articles.snippet: Seldom have the candidates’ divergent approaches to campaigning been on more vivid display than in the final days of the race.
articles.abstract: Seldom have the candidates’ divergent approaches to campaigning been on more vivid display than in the final days of the race.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saturating swing states with powerful campaign surrogates and mobilizing a vast field organization, Hillary Clinton on Thursday intensified her public attacks on Donald J. Trump as a threat to minorities in the hope of driving them to the polls in decisive numbers.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Last Economic Snapshot Before the Election Shows Healthy Job Growth
articles.snippet: While the presidential campaigns have been preoccupied with issues beyond the economy, the report refocuses attention on the crucial issue of jobs.
articles.abstract: While the presidential campaigns have been preoccupied with issues beyond the economy, the report refocuses attention on the crucial issue of jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time the unemployment rate was running this low was in early 2008. But by Election Day that year, the economy was in sad shape and getting worse by every measure. Hundreds of thousands of jobs were vanishing, housing prices were plunging, paychecks were shrinking and credit was tight.

articles.headline: These Officials Help Write Ballot Questions. Companies Write Them Checks.
articles.snippet: Secretaries of state, who oversee ballot measures on issues like gun control and the minimum wage, are courted by interest groups and industries with billions of dollars at stake.
articles.abstract: Secretaries of state, who oversee ballot measures on issues like gun control and the minimum wage, are courted by interest groups and industries with billions of dollars at stake.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Big-money corporate lobbying has reached into one of the most obscure corners of state government: the offices of secretaries of state, the people charged with running elections impartially.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Robert Faturechi

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Sees Ugliness, and Joy, in Race’s Closing Days
articles.snippet: With the finish line in sight, political headaches and quietly intense rallies have consumed Mrs. Clinton’s final week as a presidential candidate.
articles.abstract: With the finish line in sight, political headaches and quietly intense rallies have consumed Mrs. Clinton’s final week as a presidential candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Hillary Clinton stood beneath the strobe lights, her back to the palm trees — hoarse, but hiding it well, at least for a moment.

articles.headline: How to Fix a Retirement Plan at a School or Nonprofit
articles.snippet: Plans known as 403(b)’s often have mediocre investment choices and high fees; here are some ways to do something about it.
articles.abstract: Plans known as 403(b)’s often have mediocre investment choices and high fees; here are some ways to do something about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you work for a school or nonprofit of any sort, there is a decent chance that your workplace retirement savings plan is not as good as it could be — if you are lucky enough to have one at all.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: How to Satirize This Election? Even the Onion Is Having Trouble
articles.snippet: The 2016 presidential campaign, with its unsavory issues and unpopular candidates, has proved challenging to the staff of the satirical website The Onion.
articles.abstract: The 2016 presidential campaign, with its unsavory issues and unpopular candidates, has proved challenging to the staff of the satirical website The Onion.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Now that it’s almost over and we’re all thoroughly miserable, is there anything funny left to say about this dreadful election? Even the writers at the satirical website The Onion were struggling the other morning to come up with fresh avenues of amusement.
